title: Put the Fries in the Bag: TikTok Slang Explained

steps.title: The phrase is an insult that implies youâ€™re better than someone else.
steps.content: The phrase is an insult that implies youâ€™re better than someone else. People usually say "just put the fries in the bag, bro" to put someone down and insinuate that they have no career prospects beyond being a fast food worker. It originated from a meme posted on Facebook in 2022 depicting a fictional exchange between an employee and customer at a fast food restaurant. The employee says, â€œI ainâ€™t seen you since high school,â€ and the customer replies, â€œJust put my ketchup in the bag bro." [1] X Research source In this context, the phrase is a pretty harsh insult, since it dismisses the employee as unimportant and implies that theyâ€™re inferior to the customer. Itâ€™s essentially a way to say that you think someone is a loser, so itâ€™s a pretty low blow. As the phrase grew in popularity, the word â€œketchupâ€ was swapped out for â€œfries.â€ [2] X Research source

The other character in the skit ends the interaction by saying â€œjust put my fries in the bag, bro,â€ as a way to put the original character down and imply he has no prospects beyond an eventual fast food career.

steps.title: To put others down for lack of success or career prospects
steps.content: To put others down for lack of success or career prospects If someone shares a business idea or career plan that seems unlikely or far-fetched, another person may reply, â€œjust put the fries in the bag, bro,â€ to imply that this path will end with them working at a fast food restaurant. How are you going to support yourself with that? Just put the fries in the bag, bro.â€

steps.title: As a belittling spam comment on TikTok
steps.content: As a belittling spam comment on TikTok Users comment â€œjust put the fries in the bag, broâ€ on TikTok videos to belittle or shame the original poster. This often occurs when users feel like the poster is speaking on something theyâ€™re not qualified to talk about, sharing a business idea that makes no sense, or simply saying something the commenter doesnâ€™t agree with. For example, if someone posted a TikTok about how theyâ€™re starting a mental health counseling service even though they have no official training, someone might comment, â€œJust put the fries in the bag, bro.â€

steps.content: To remind someone to stay on topic In the context of the original Facebook meme, the customer uses the phrase to convey that they arenâ€™t interested in reminiscing with their old high school classmate at the fast food restaurantâ€”they just want to get their food and go home. As a result, â€œjust put the fries in the bagâ€ can also be a way to tell someone to stop going off on tangents and get to the point, so both parties can move on. [4] X Research source For example, if youâ€™re asking a friend for help with a math problem at school, but they keep getting distracted and rambling about how their weekend went, you might say, â€œjust put the fries in the bag, bro,â€ to bring them back to the topic at hand. steps.title: If someone says this phrase to you, it can be pretty hurtful.
steps.content: If someone says this phrase to you, it can be pretty hurtful. Maybe you were sharing an idea about your future, and a friend said â€œput the fries in the bagâ€ to dismiss your plan as silly or stupid. Even if they were joking, this insult can be very upsetting, and youâ€™re well within your rights to let them know that youâ€™re offended. [6] X Research source Focus on your feelings and use â€œIâ€ statements to explain how their comment impacted you. Here are some examples: â€œI was trying to share a plan I was excited about, and I feel like I was immediately dismissed and made fun of. I know you were joking around, but I actually feel upset.â€ â€œI already feel stressed about my career plans, so that comment was extra hurtful. It made me feel like you think I have no potential.â€

steps.title: â€œPut the fries in the bagâ€ can be a hurtful insult.
steps.content: â€œPut the fries in the bagâ€ can be a hurtful insult. The phrase is used to belittle someone, imply that youâ€™re better than them, and insinuate that they have no career prospects. This is pretty harsh! Itâ€™s also problematic that the phrase compares someone to a fast food worker as a way to put them down. Thereâ€™s absolutely nothing wrong with working at a fast food restaurant, and itâ€™s unkind to imply that this career path makes someone inferior to you. Although itâ€™s possible to say â€œput the fries in the bagâ€ in a lighthearted, joke-y way, you never know who might be genuinely hurt by this insult. Additionally, this phrase doesnâ€™t just insult the person on the receiving endâ€”it also insults fast food workers in general, which is not very nice. Because of all this, itâ€™s a good idea to think twice before using it.
